facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 253 of 1968 by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated April 12, 1968

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 253 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated April 12, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Govt. Appeal No. 13 of 1965 and Criminal Govt. Appeal No. 10 of 1966.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court restored Magistrate's conviction order in Criminal Govt. Appeal No. 13 of 1965 and No. 10 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 253 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated April 12, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Govt. Appeal No. 13 of 1965 and Criminal Govt. Appeal No. 10 of 1966.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted appellant under section 16 read with section 7 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment and fine Rs. 1000 or six months more

anchor.surface_text: restored the order of the Magistrate companyvicting the appellant of an offence under section 16 read with section 7. of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act  Act 37 of 1954 , hereinafter called the Act, and sentencing him to undergo one years rigorous imprisonment and pay a fine of Rs. 1,000/- and in default of payment of fine to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a further period of six months,

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted appellant in appeal

anchor.surface_text: after reversing the order passed by the Sessions Judge in appeal acquitting him of the offence.

facts.text: On June 13, 1963 Head Constable Baboo Khan on patrol duty came to Chakki of Abdul Razaaq and saw heap of Shakkar with labourers mixing Shelkhari in it

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1963, Head Constable Baboo Khan was on patrol duty. He happened to companye to the Chakki of one Abdul Razaaq. There he found a heap of Shakkar and some labourers mixing Shelkhari in it with spades.

facts.text: Head Constable informed Station Officer who was not there, then met Sanitary Inspector

anchor.surface_text: He went to the police station to inform the Station Officer about it but the Station Officer was number there. He then met the Sanitary Inspector and informed him about what he, saw at the Chakki.

facts.text: Sanitary Inspector accompanied by Food Inspector proceeded to Chakki and found labourers mixing Shelkhari with Shakkar

anchor.surface_text: The Sanitary Inspector accompanied by the Food Inspector proceeded to the Chakki and there, they found the labourers mixing Shelkhari with Shakkar.

facts.text: Stock of Shakkar belonged to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The stock of Shakkar belonged to the appellant.

facts.text: Food Inspector purchased 1-1/2 seers of Shakkar from appellant as sample after paying price

anchor.surface_text: The Food Inspector purchased 1- 1/2 seers of Shakkar from the appellant by way of sample after paying its price.

facts.text: Food Inspector divided sample into three parts, gave one to appellant, retained two, sent one to Public Analyst

anchor.surface_text: He divided the sample into three parts, gave one to the appellant and retained the other two with him. One of the samples retained was sent to the Public Analyst for examination.

facts.text: Public Analyst report dated July 11, 1963 found Shakkar contained 2.4% moisture, 72.7% total sugar, 64.7% sucrose, 17% extraneous matter insoluble in water

anchor.surface_text: The Analyst found, in his report dated July 11, 1963, that the Shakkar companytained 2.4 moisture, 72.7 total sugar, 64.7 sucrose, 17 extraneous matter insoluble in water.

facts.text: Analyst found extraneous matter insoluble in water exceeded by 15%, total ash by 10.1%, ash insoluble in HCl by 13.3% against standards 2.0, 6.0, 0.5

anchor.surface_text: According to him the extraneous matter insoluble in water, total ash and ash insoluble in Hydrochloric acid exceeded by 15,O, 10.1 and 13.3 respectively as against the maximum prescribed standards of 2.0, 6.0 and O.5 respectively.

facts.text: Complaint filed by Food Inspector of Municipal Board Saharanpur

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of a companyplaint filed by the Food Inspector of the Municipal Board, Saharanpur,

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted because prosecution not proved Shakkar stored for sale, was for converting to Rab, no standard for Shakkar, not gur or jaggery, sale to FI under duress

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge acquitted him of the offence for the reason that the prosecution had numberproved that the Shakkar stored by the appellant was for sale.He said that the appellant was mixing extraneous matter with the Shakkar for companyverting it into Rab and as such it cannotbe said that the Shakkar was stored for sale by the appellant.He also said that numberstandard of quality was prescribed by therules framed under the Act for Shakkar, that as an article of food, Shakkar was neither gur number Jaggery and that the sale of Shakkar to the Food Inspector by the appellant was under duress and was number a sale in the eye of the law.

facts.text: High Court held Shakkar is same as jaggery, standard prescribed for jaggery, Shakkar adulterated, sample to FI is sale under s.2(xiii), FI power even if stored for manufacturing Rab

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that Shakkar is same as jaggery, that standard of quality has been prescribed by the rules framed under the Act for jaggery, that the Shakkar in question was adulterated, that the sample purchased by the Food Inspector for the purpose of analysis amounted to sale within the meaning of section 2  xiii  of the Act, that Food Inspector had power under the Act to get the sample even if the Shakkar was stored for being manufactured into Rab and number for sale

facts.text: Appellant contention that Shakkar is not jaggery and no standard prescribed for Shakkar

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention on behalf of the appellant was that Shakkar is number jaggery, and since numberstandard of quality has been prescribed for Shakkar under the rules formed under the Act, the Shakkar was number adulterated.

facts.text: Appendix B Para A.07.05 defines Gur or jaggery as product from sugarcane juice boiling etc., standards given

anchor.surface_text: Para A.07.05 of Appendix B of the Rules reads Gur or jaggery means the product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed out of sugar cane or extracted from palmyra palm, date palm or companyonut palm. It shall be free from substances deleterious to health and shall companyform to the following analytical standards on dry weight basis total sugars number less than 90 per cent and sucrose number less than 70 per cent. extraneous matter insoluble in water number more than 2 per cent. 3 5 3 total ash number more than 6 per cent. ash insoluble in hydrochloric acid  HCI  number more than O.5 per cent. Gur or jaggery other than that of the liquid or semi-liquid variety shall number companytain more than 10 per cent moisture.

facts.text: Not disputed that Shakkar is product obtained by boiling sugarcane juice

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that Shakkar is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed from out of sugarcane, and therefore, it is clear that Shakkar is jaggery.

facts.text: Appellant contention that Shakkar stored for manufacturing Rab, not for sale

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention on behalf of the appellant was that he had kept the Shakkar for manufacturing Rab out of it. The companytention, in other words, is that he had number kept the Shakkar for sale but kept it for manufacturing Rab out of it

facts.text: High Court finding that Shakkar kept for purpose of sale, not for manufacturing Rab, mixing Shelkhari to sell as food

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that the Shakkar was kept by the appellant for the purpose of sale and number for the purpose of manufacturing Rab out of it and that the attempt of the appellant was to sell the Shakkar as an article, of food after mixing Shelkhari with it.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld that Shakkar is jaggery and adulterated per analyst report

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to accept the companytention that Shakkar is number Jaggery. ... It is, therefore, clear that Shakkar is jaggery and the finding of the High Court, on the basis of the report of the Analyst, that the Shakkar has number companyformed to the standard of quality prescribed for jaggery and, therefore, the food was adulterated, was companyrect and has to be maintained.

facts.text: Sale to Food Inspector is a sale under the Act even if not dealer or not kept for sale

anchor.surface_text: And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act. In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gapalan and another  , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or number, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be companyvicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act. In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether Shakkar is jaggery/gur as defined in Para A.07.05 of Appendix B to the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules and therefore subject to the prescribed standards of quality, rendering it adulterated?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention on behalf of the appellant was that Shakkar is not jaggery, and since no standard of quality has been prescribed for Shakkar under the rules framed under the Act, the Shakkar was not adulterated. We find it difficult to accept the contention that Shakkar is not Jaggery.

issues.text: Whether the Shakkar was stored for sale or for the purpose of manufacturing it into Rab?

anchor.surface_text: The second contention on behalf of the appellant was that he had kept the Shakkar for manufacturing Rab out of it. The contention, in other words, is that he had not kept the Shakkar for sale but kept it for manufacturing Rab out of it and, therefore, the conviction under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act was bad.

issues.text: Whether a sale of an adulterated article of food to a Food Inspector constitutes a 'sale' for the purposes of sections 7 and 16 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, even if not kept for sale or the seller is not a dealer?

anchor.surface_text: And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act. In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act.

It is not disputed that Shakkar is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed from out of sugarcane, and therefore, it is clear that Shakkar is jaggery.

arguments.claim: Dictionary defines jaggery as coarse dark sugar made from palm sap or otherwise, Hindi Shakkar

arguments.claim: Shakkar kept for purpose of sale, not for manufacturing Rab; attempt to sell after mixing Shelkhari

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that the Shakkar was kept by the appellant for the purpose of sale and not for the purpose of manufacturing Rab out of it and that the attempt of the appellant was to sell the Shakkar as an article, of food after mixing Shelkhari with it.

arguments.qualifiers: We see no reason to think that the finding was wrong

arguments.claim: Even if Shakkar kept for manufacturing Rab not sale, sale to Food Inspector constitutes offence under sections 7 and 16

anchor.surface_text: But assuming that the finding was wrong and that the appellant kept the Shakkar not for sale but for manufacturing Rab out of it, what follows? If Shakkar is an article of food, it does not matter whether the appellant kept it for sale... And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Sale to Food Inspector triggers liability under section 16 r/w 7 even if not dealer or not kept for sale, following Food Inspector Calicut v. Charukattil Gopalan

anchor.surface_text: In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another, this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act.

holdings.text: Shakkar is jaggery as it is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed out of sugarcane, and therefore subject to standards in Para A.07.05 of Appendix B; the Shakkar did not conform to those standards per analyst report and was adulterated

anchor.surface_text: Para A.07.05 of Appendix B of the Rules reads Gur or jaggery means the product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed out of sugar cane or extracted from palmyra palm, date palm or coconut palm. It shall be free from substances deleterious to health and shall conform to the following analytical standards on dry weight basis total sugars not less than 90 per cent and sucrose not less than 70 per cent. extraneous matter insoluble in water not more than 2 per cent. 3 5 3 total ash not more than 6 per cent. ash insoluble in hydrochloric acid  HCI  not more than O.5 per cent. Gur or jaggery other than that of the liquid or semi-liquid variety shall not contain more than 10 per cent moisture. It is not disputed that Shakkar is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed from out of sugarcane, and therefore, it is clear that Shakkar is jaggery.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies textual definition in rules to undisputed fact of Shakkar's production process and analyst's findings of non-conformity

holdings.text: The finding that Shakkar was kept for purpose of sale and not for manufacturing Rab, with intent to sell after mixing Shelkhari, is correct

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that the Shakkar was kept by the appellant for the purpose of sale and not for the purpose of manufacturing Rab out of it and that the attempt of the appellant was to sell the Shakkar as an article, of food after mixing Shelkhari with it. We see no reason to think that the finding was wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts and upholds High Court's factual finding on intent based on evidence of mixing and storage

holdings.text: Even if Shakkar was stored not for sale but for manufacturing into Rab, storing or selling adulterated food violates section 7, and punishment applies under section 16 upon sale to Food Inspector

anchor.surface_text: But assuming that the finding was wrong and that the appellant kept the Shakkar not for sale but for manufacturing Rab out of it, what follows? If Shakkar is an article of food, it does not matter whether the appellant kept it for sale, or for manufacturing Rab out of it, provided the appellant has sold it. And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetically assumes contrary fact but applies provisions of sections 7 and 16 literally to sale event

holdings.text: Sale of adulterated food article to Food Inspector constitutes 'sale' under section 16 read with section 7 even if seller is not a dealer and article not kept for sale; liable for conviction

anchor.surface_text: In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act. The respondents before this Court in that case were the manager and owner of a tea stall. The case against them was that they sold 600 grains of sugar to the appellant, the Food Inspector, for analysis and that the sugar was adulterated. ... we see no reason to doubt the correctness of the ratio of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding Supreme Court precedent applying sections 2(xiii), 7 and 16 to sales to inspectors irrespective of commercial intent

holdings.text: High Court conclusion restoring Magistrate's conviction and sentence under section 16 read with section 7 is correct

anchor.surface_text: We think the High Court was right in its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts and law upholds conviction

precedents.case_name: Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another
precedents.cited_proposition: sale to Food Inspector constitutes a sale for purposes of section 16 of the Act even if the article was not kept for sale and the seller is not a dealer in the article; liability under section 16 read with section 7 if the food is adulterated
precedents.cited_holding: sale to a Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act, that the article of food sold to the Food Inspector need not have been taken from a larger quantity kept for sale, and that the person by whom the article of food was sold to the Food Inspector need not be a dealer as such in the article

anchor.surface_text: Para A.07.05 of Appendix B of the Rules reads Gur or jaggery means the product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed out of sugar cane or extracted from palmyra palm, date palm or coconut palm. It shall be free from substances deleterious to health and shall conform to the following analytical standards on dry weight basis total sugars not less than 90 per cent and sucrose not less than 70 per cent. extraneous matter insoluble in water not more than 2 per cent. 3 5 3 total ash not more than 6 per cent. ash insoluble in hydrochloric acid  HCI  not more than O.5 per cent. Gur or jaggery other than that of the liquid or semi-liquid variety shall not contain more than 10 per cent moisture. It is not disputed that Shakkar is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed from out of sugarcane, and therefore, it is clear that Shakkar is jaggery.

Para A.07.05 of Appendix B of the Rules reads Gur or jaggery means the product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed out of sugar cane or extracted from palmyra palm, date palm or coconut palm. It shall be free from substances deleterious to health and shall conform to the following analytical standards on dry weight basis total sugars not less than 90 per cent and sucrose not less than 70 per cent. extraneous matter insoluble in water not more than 2 per cent. 3 5 3 total ash not more than 6 per cent. ash insoluble in hydrochloric acid  HCI  not more than O.5 per cent. Gur or jaggery other than that of the liquid or semi-liquid variety shall not contain more than 10 per cent moisture. It is not disputed that Shakkar is a product obtained by boiling or processing juice pressed from out of sugarcane, and therefore, it is clear that Shakkar is jaggery.

edges.explanation: Holding that storage was for sale addresses the issue of storage purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that the Shakkar was kept by the appellant for the purpose of sale and not for the purpose of manufacturing Rab out of it and that the attempt of the appellant was to sell the Shakkar as an article, of food after mixing Shelkhari with it. We see no reason to think that the finding was wrong.

The finding of the High Court is that the Shakkar was kept by the appellant for the purpose of sale and not for the purpose of manufacturing Rab out of it and that the attempt of the appellant was to sell the Shakkar as an article, of food after mixing Shelkhari with it. We see no reason to think that the finding was wrong.

edges.explanation: Holding that violation even if not stored for sale addresses the storage purpose issue.

anchor.surface_text: But assuming that the finding was wrong and that the appellant kept the Shakkar not for sale but for manufacturing Rab out of it, what follows? If Shakkar is an article of food, it does not matter whether the appellant kept it for sale, or for manufacturing Rab out of it, provided the appellant has sold it. And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act.

But assuming that the finding was wrong and that the appellant kept the Shakkar not for sale but for manufacturing Rab out of it, what follows? If Shakkar is an article of food, it does not matter whether the appellant kept it for sale, or for manufacturing Rab out of it, provided the appellant has sold it. And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act. The respondents before this Court in that case were the manager and owner of a tea stall. The case against them was that they sold 600 grains of sugar to the appellant, the Food Inspector, for analysis and that the sugar was adulterated. ... we see no reason to doubt the correctness of the ratio of the case.

In The Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gopalan and another , this Court held that, if any articles of food are sold by any person, whether he be a dealer in them or not, and if the food is adulterated, he is liable to be convicted under section 16 read with section 7 of the Act. The respondents before this Court in that case were the manager and owner of a tea stall. The case against them was that they sold 600 grains of sugar to the appellant, the Food Inspector, for analysis and that the sugar was adulterated. ... we see no reason to doubt the correctness of the ratio of the case.
We think the High Court was right in its conclusion.
